text: Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say. Doctor: Okay, well my sense is you know he and I can talk about sort of when’s the right time to get new pictures, and the lung stuff is interesting because is it just cancer in your lung that causing this gasping, this wheezing? Patient: He doesn’t think so. Doctor: I don’t think so either, but you’d have to rule that out because that can complicate sometimes clinical trials- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because using experimental therapies in somebody who’s got something else going wrong that’s not the cancer or the therapy- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: when you’re on a trial we can sometimes blame the new drug for that symptom and then that drug gets a black eye. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So companies want to make sure that you’re good to go on and they’re not going to get a black eye because there’s something going on that’s not related to what they’re doing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yes, understand.

text: Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: Hospitalized? Patient: No. Doctor: And you’re here today because you had a follow-up or other reasons? Patient: For a follow-up, yeah, yeah. They took blood last time, and ran some protocols and you were going to check on some numbers. Doctor: Anything new on your body that you’ve noticed that you want me to take a look at? Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds) Doctor: A little bit. No bumps at all up here. No pain, no itching. Patient: No. I noticed some weakness in my right leg. Doctor: They drew blood today. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Last week? Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. This is December and this is last week – up point five.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that? Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: He tells me every time you see him once a month because he draws blood work and everything so then I know you pop up in my systems like oh, you’re in the systems. text: Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: The super hormones for the three months also make you more tired, but not really that much more because once we lower your testosterone down to what we call castrate levels, to go from castrate to super castrate, people don’t complain about more tiredness. Patient: Right. Doctor: So um there are some things we watch and your blood tests to make sure you’re tolerating the drugs all right, but that’s not the big issue. Tiredness is the issue. So then we add chemo in and really we give the chemo to you four times on a Monday – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - three weeks apart. Um, the the actual um chemo itself, you don’t get sick, you don’t throw up. We have all the medicines that stop that from happening. Anything that throw up We’re just really good at it. Uhm, Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Because that’s what everybody gets. That’s what everybody gets. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So. You know. Doctor: Yeah. It ends up boiling down to your time on this study. And again, someone close by or regional, it, it makes some sense, you know, huh, and you could always back out if it’s just too crazy to come in. You know? We’re are going to try to get you at least the first cycle of this to sort of get the data on you about side effects, what you’re feeling, what you’re not feeling, huh, and that. Huh, so it sounds to me like you’re open to the idea. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But we don’t have to commit today to sort of say, yeah, I’m doing it, huh, because we also have to check your insurance. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah.

text: Family Member: So we’re still kind of up in the air because this is nothing we can cure because of the type of cancer that it is and there’s no option to remove the lymph node. I don’t know Doctor: That’s correct. Family Member: That’s correct. Okay, okay. So with him trying to maintain quality of life and, and, and, uhm you know stay upright knowing that he has this and that he’s against hormone therapy but also still leaning with the fact that there’s the other foot to drop. Doctor: Uh hum. Family Member: You’re saying the radiation is a viable option if that’s the route he chooses to go but your recommendation is hormone? Doctor: No actually open to both; it all depends on your current wishes. If your wish is to preserve your quality of life as much as possible for as long as possible – Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - then there’s no question that hormone therapy will cause more side effects than radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: There’s no question about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, if your goal is to try to eradicate as much of the cancer as fast as possible –

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: My sense is that this really was a new baseline just to make sure we're, you know, again, it's unusual for this to be real. Patient: Right. Doctor: But it's a possibility. I mean I just had a patient just before you his PSA was point three, something showed up, we put a biopsy and guess what it was prostate cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but that's not the norm. It doesn't make sense. And yet that's an example where it shows possibility. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know with you, you know what I worry about is sometimes you know, we write prostate cancer on the order form so the doctor over says, “Oh, yeah, there it is, there it is.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they may be right, or they may be calling what we normally if you had a scan and they’d say, “ that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis”. Patient: Right. Doctor: Prostate Cancer likes to go to the lymph nodes, and so they're oft- they have to start small. And so we all have lymph nodes, but in this case, they say yeah, there’s lymph nodes-

text: Patient: Right. I don’t have to be a rabbit anymore? We might have to change this little tail that I’m growing. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He lost seven pounds in a week. (Laughter) Doctor: It’s really key. Don’t let people take your money for crazy stuff. Patient: Right, okay. Family Member: We’re just afraid, to be honest with you, is like you know we feel a little helpless here this conversation with you, but I think what we’re trying to do is like figure out ____ like what can I do to like to cause it to get worse. Doctor: Stay thin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s that simple. I mean when you look across all the thousands of guys with prostate cancer and all the different things out there, the bottom line is don’t get fat. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: And how will you do that? It doesn’t matter. It’s the fact that you don’t. Patient: Right. Family Member: And now I have a question, and you can tell me if you know how to answer this but you know you’re saying here you’re giving us all our options. text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Those are the seminal vessels. (Pause 10 seconds) Family Member: And this, we were just surprised because there’s nothing that would indicate all that. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: His PSA being low, and the prostate not being enlarged, and the preliminary report they told us we thought when you called down that day we were here. Doctor: I know. I’m really upset by passing incorrect information to you based on the verbal report. That’s the danger of doing that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. I’m like what were you looking at? The other sixteen lymph nodes first? (Laughs) Patient: We’re hoping you got the samples switched or something like that. Doctor: You know I was actually gonna check that and I haven’t done that. The big question is did anybody else have prostate surgery on the same day. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Mm, hmm. Doctor: Not by me, but it could be another doctor. Family Member: I would like to check it just for peace of mind only, but there’s nothing that would lead us to think it was all this and to be fifty to sixty percent involved with the prostate kind of blew our minds a little bit. Doctor: Me too. Yeah.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
